title: Create a Coffee Mug
description: Learn to model a complete coffee mug with handle using revolve, shell, and sweep operations.

steps.title: Start a New Sketch
steps.instruction: Click on the XZ plane (Front plane) in the Origin folder to create a new sketch for the mug profile.
steps.detailedText: We'll create the mug body using a Revolve operation, which spins a 2D profile around an axis. Starting on the XZ plane lets us draw the cross-section of the mug and revolve it around the Y-axis to create a symmetrical cylindrical shape.

visualStep.caption: Expand Origin in the Browser and click on the XZ plane

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: Revolve is ideal for creating symmetrical objects like mugs, vases, and bowls.
tips: The XZ plane is vertical - perfect for drawing the mug's side profile
You can also right-click on the plane and select 'Create Sketch'
The origin will be at the center bottom of your mug

qcChecks.text: You are in sketch editing mode

warnings.text: Make sure to select XZ plane, not XY plane

steps.title: Draw the Mug Profile
steps.instruction: Use the Line tool (L) to draw the mug's cross-section. Start at the origin, go up 90mm, right 35mm, down 85mm, then right 5mm and down 5mm to create the base.
steps.detailedText: This L-shaped profile represents half of the mug's cross-section. When revolved, it will create the outer and inner walls. The 5mm bottom thickness ensures a sturdy base.

visualStep.caption: Select the Line tool from CREATE menu or press L

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: Drawing only half the profile is efficient because Revolve will mirror it automatically.
tips: Press L to quickly activate the Line tool
Type dimensions directly while drawing for precision
Keep lines connected - gaps will cause revolve to fail

warnings.text: Draw on the RIGHT side of the Y-axis only

steps.title: Close the Profile
steps.instruction: Complete the profile by drawing a line from the bottom right corner back to the origin along the center axis.
steps.detailedText: The profile must be completely closed for the Revolve command to work. This bottom line along the axis will become the center of the mug's base when revolved.

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: Fusion 360 requires closed profiles for most 3D operations.
tips: Click exactly on the origin point to close the profile
A closed profile will show as a shaded region

steps.title: Finish the Sketch
steps.instruction: Click 'Finish Sketch' in the toolbar or press Escape to exit sketch mode.
steps.detailedText: Always finish your sketch before applying 3D operations. This locks the geometry and makes it available for the Revolve command.

tips: Green checkmark in toolbar = Finish Sketch
Press Escape as a shortcut

steps.title: Revolve the Profile
steps.instruction: Go to Create > Revolve (or press R), select your profile, and choose the Y-axis as the revolution axis. Set angle to 360 degrees.
steps.detailedText: Revolve spins your 2D profile around an axis to create a 3D solid. By revolving 360 degrees around the vertical axis, your L-shaped profile becomes a hollow cylinder - the basic mug body.

visualStep.caption: Click CREATE dropdown, then select Revolve

requires.reason: The Revolve tool is in the Solid modeling environment

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: Revolve is perfect for any object with circular symmetry.
tips: The axis must be on the edge of or outside your profile
You can revolve less than 360 degrees for partial shapes

warnings.text: If revolve fails, check that profile doesn't cross the axis

steps.title: Create Handle Sketch
steps.instruction: Create a new sketch on the XZ plane. We'll draw the handle's path on the side of the mug.
steps.detailedText: The handle will be created using a Sweep operation, which requires two sketches: a path (the curve the handle follows) and a profile (the cross-section shape).

visualStep.caption: Click on XZ plane in Origin folder to start a new sketch

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: Sweep is ideal for creating handles, pipes, and any shape that follows a curved path.
tips: The XZ plane passes through the center of the mug
Position the handle path to connect with the mug's outer surface

qcChecks.text: New sketch started on XZ plane

steps.title: Draw Handle Path
steps.instruction: Use the 3-Point Arc tool to draw a C-shaped handle path. Start 15mm from the top, arc outward 25mm, and end 20mm from the bottom.
steps.detailedText: The handle path defines the shape of your handle. A smooth arc creates an ergonomic grip.

visualStep.caption: Find 3-Point Arc in CREATE > Arc dropdown

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: Handle ergonomics matter! The arc should provide enough space for fingers.
tips: Use 3-Point Arc for smooth curves
First click: top attachment point
Second click: bottom attachment point
Third click: controls the arc's bulge

qcChecks.text: Arc starts at mug surface level
Arc ends at mug surface level

warnings.text: Path should not intersect the mug body

steps.title: Create Handle Profile Sketch
steps.instruction: Finish the path sketch, then create a new sketch perpendicular to the path at its starting point. Draw a 10mm x 8mm rounded rectangle for the handle cross-section.
steps.detailedText: The profile sketch defines the shape of the handle's cross-section. An oval or rounded rectangle is comfortable to grip.

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: The profile shape affects both comfort and strength.
tips: Create sketch on a plane perpendicular to the path start
Center the profile on the path endpoint

warnings.text: Profile must be on a plane perpendicular to the path

steps.title: Sweep the Handle
steps.instruction: Go to Create > Sweep. Select the rounded rectangle as the Profile and the arc as the Path. Set Operation to 'Join' to merge with the mug body.
steps.detailedText: Sweep extrudes a profile along a path, creating the 3D handle. Using 'Join' operation automatically merges the handle with the mug body.

visualStep.caption: Click CREATE dropdown, then select Sweep

requires.reason: The Sweep tool is in the Solid modeling environment

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: The Join operation makes the handle and mug body one continuous solid.
tips: Select Profile first, then Path
If it doesn't join, check that surfaces are touching

warnings.text: If sweep fails, ensure profile is perpendicular to path

steps.title: Add Fillet to Rim
steps.instruction: Select the Fillet tool (F), click on the top inner and outer edges of the mug rim, and set radius to 2mm.
steps.detailedText: Filleting the rim makes it comfortable to drink from and removes sharp edges that could chip.

visualStep.caption: Find Fillet in MODIFY dropdown or press F

requires.reason: The Fillet tool is in the Solid modeling environment

tips: Select both inner and outer rim edges
Hold Ctrl to select multiple edges
2mm is comfortable for drinking

steps.title: Fillet Handle Joints
steps.instruction: Add 5mm fillets where the handle meets the mug body to create smooth transitions.
steps.detailedText: Filleting the handle-to-body joints strengthens the connection and creates an organic, professional look.

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: The handle attachment points experience the most stress. Fillets reduce stress concentration.
tips: Select the edges where handle meets mug body
Larger radius = stronger joint

warnings.text: If fillet fails, try a smaller radius

steps.title: Add Base Fillet
steps.instruction: Add a 3mm fillet to the bottom outer edge of the mug for a finished look.
steps.detailedText: A small fillet on the base edge prevents chipping and gives the mug a refined appearance.

tips: 3mm is enough to protect without changing the look dramatically

steps.title: Review Your Mug
steps.instruction: Rotate the view to inspect your completed mug from all angles. Check handle attachment, wall thickness, and overall proportions.
steps.detailedText: Always review your model from multiple angles before exporting or printing.

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: Quality checking catches issues before they become expensive mistakes.
tips: Use Section Analysis to check wall thickness
Orbit around to see all sides
finalChecklist: Handle is attached at both ends

steps.title: Congratulations!
steps.instruction: You've successfully modeled a coffee mug! Your mug is ready for rendering, 3D printing, or further customization.
steps.detailedText: You've learned essential CAD techniques: Revolve for symmetrical bodies, Sweep for handles and tubes, and strategic filleting for both aesthetics and strength.

expandedContent.whyThisMatters: The techniques you've learned are fundamental to product design.
nextSteps: Try adding a logo or text to the mug surface
